title: General Information About Data
text:
General Information About Data
The data was provided by the We Will Announce Femicides Platform and a counter bot that automatically runs every time a femicide news item hits the system. The data was scraped from the internet. The values we have in general. It includes information such as provinces, proximity status, the reason for the killing, the manner of killing and the status of the perpetrator.
rdata


Why This Dataset Was Chosen:

Femicide is one of the most critical societal issues in Turkey, and analyzing it from a data-driven perspective can provide meaningful insights into its root causes and trends.
The dataset is open access, reliable, and directly relevant to Turkey.
It allows for both spatial and temporal analysis of femicide incidents.
The findings could contribute to awareness campaigns and data-informed policy recommendations.



Our Goals
We will try to remove the raw data and make it ready for analysis. While unnecessary columns are removed. There will be columns that we need to make corrections and we will also create new columns. By removing repetitive data in our data set, we will make the data ready to work Objectives and Goals: - Primary Objective: - Our goal is to analyze femicide cases across Turkey, focusing on changes over time, identifying regional hotspots, and exploring the relationship with socio-economic and cultural factors. - Investigate whether femicide rates have been increasing or decreasing over the years. - Map regional hotspots and explore the relationships between femicide cases and variables such as population density, education levels, and economic conditions. - Examine the profiles of perpetrators and victims to understand risk factors. - Provide actionable insights that can contribute to policy formulation and support advocacy campaigns.

1 Since this data was taken from the news source, repetitive values due to surname entries were present in 4 years, but now these values have been eliminated by calculating the proximity between texts and using the algorithm. Afterwards, unnecessary code repetition was avoided with a loop



Code
library(dplyr)
library(stringdist)


Warning: package 'stringdist' was built under R version 4.4.1


Code
years <- 2020:2024

threshold <- 0.23
cleaned_data_list <- list()


for (year in years) {
  file_name <- paste0("anitsayac_full_data_", year, ".csv")
  data <- read.csv(file_name, stringsAsFactors = FALSE)
  
  data <- data %>%
    mutate(
      Similar_Group = apply(
        stringdistmatrix(Ad.Soyad., Ad.Soyad., method = "jw"), 
        1, 
        function(x) which(x < threshold)[1]  
      )
    )
  
  cleaned_data <- data %>%
    group_by(Similar_Group) %>%
    slice(1)  
  
  cleaned_data_list[[as.character(year)]] <- cleaned_data
  
  
}

# İl ve İlçeleri Bölgelerine Göre Gruplama Fonksiyonu
ilce_to_region <- function(ilce) {
  marmara <- c("İstanbul", "Bursa", "Edirne", "Tekirdağ", "Kocaeli", "Yalova", "Çanakkale", "Balıkesir", "Sakarya", "Düzce", "Bilecik", "Silivri", "İzmit", "Gebze", "Arnavutköy", "Gemlik", "Çorlu")
  ege <- c("İzmir", "Aydın", "Manisa", "Denizli", "Muğla", "Uşak", "Afyonkarahisar", "Kütahya", "Bodrum", "Didim", "Fethiye", "Alanya", "Ödemiş", "Buca")
  karadeniz <- c("Trabzon", "Rize", "Samsun", "Ordu", "Giresun", "Zonguldak", "Bartın", "Sinop", "Amasya", "Çorum", "Kastamonu", "Karabük", "Tokat", "Artvin", "Gümüşhane", "Osmancık")
  akdeniz <- c("Antalya", "Adana", "Mersin", "Hatay", "Osmaniye", "Burdur", "Isparta", "Kahramanmaraş", "Gazipaşa", "Marmaris")
  ic_anadolu <- c("Ankara", "Eskişehir", "Konya", "Kayseri", "Sivas", "Niğde", "Aksaray", "Karaman", "Kırıkkale", "Kırşehir", "Nevşehir", "Yozgat", "Çankırı", "Sincan", "Polatlı")
  dogu_anadolu <- c("Erzurum", "Van", "Malatya", "Elazığ", "Ağrı", "Iğdır", "Muş", "Bitlis", "Kars", "Hakkari", "Bingöl", "Ardahan", "Tunceli", "Erzincan")
  guneydogu_anadolu <- c("Diyarbakır", "Gaziantep", "Şanlıurfa", "Mardin", "Batman", "Siirt", "Adıyaman", "Kilis", "Şırnak", "Urfa", "ŞanlıUrfa")
  
  if (ilce %in% marmara) return("Marmara")
  if (ilce %in% ege) return("Ege")
  if (ilce %in% karadeniz) return("Karadeniz")
  if (ilce %in% akdeniz) return("Akdeniz")
  if (ilce %in% ic_anadolu) return("İç Anadolu")
  if (ilce %in% dogu_anadolu) return("Doğu Anadolu")
  if (ilce %in% guneydogu_anadolu) return("Güneydoğu Anadolu")
  return("Tespit Edilemeyen")
}

library(plotly)

combined_data <- read_csv('combined_data.csv',show_col_types = FALSE)

filtered_data <- subset(combined_data, Year != "2010")

yearly_counts <- as.data.frame(table(filtered_data$Year)) 
colnames(yearly_counts) <- c("Year", "Incident_Count") 

yearly_counts$Year <- as.numeric(as.character(yearly_counts$Year)) 
yearly_counts <- yearly_counts[order(yearly_counts$Year), ] 

plot_ly(
  data = yearly_counts,
  x = ~Year,
  y = ~Incident_Count,
  type = 'scatter',
  mode = 'lines+markers',
  line = list(color = 'blue'),
  marker = list(color = 'red', size = 8)
) %>%
  layout(
    title = "Number of Murders by Year ",
    xaxis = list(title = "Year"),
    yaxis = list(title = "Number of Murders"),
    hovermode = "closest"
  )






When we look at the number of people who have died from femicides over the years, it seems that there has been an increase in the number. The reasons for this increase can be explained by social, economic or political factors.

title: Adalet Savunucuları
text: Bu projede, 2020’den 2024 yılına kadar Türkiye’de meydana gelen kadın cinayetleri vakalarını veri analizi yöntemleriyle inceledik. Emniyet kayıtları, medya haberleri ve sivil toplum örgütlerinin raporları gibi çeşitli veri kaynaklarından yararlanarak, kadına yönelik şiddet ve cinayet vakalarıyla ilgili kapsamlı bir veri seti oluşturduk. Bu veri setini analiz ederek, kadın cinayetlerinin yıllara göre dağılımını, demografik özelliklerini, faillerle ilgili bulguları ve diğer önemli örüntüleri ortaya koyduk. Elde ettiğimiz sonuçlar, Türkiye’de kadına yönelik şiddetle mücadele çabalarına ışık tutacak niteliktedir.

title: Adalet Savunucuları
text:
2020-2024 döneminde Türkiye’de kadın cinayetleri vakalarında üzücü bir artış eğilimi gözlenmiştir.
Cinayetlerin önemli bir kısmı, kadınların yakın ilişkide olduğu erkekler (eş, partner, aile üyesi vb.) tarafından işlenmiştir.
Mağdurların yaş, eğitim düzeyi ve sosyo-ekonomik statü gibi demografik özellikleri incelendiğinde, şiddetin toplumun her kesiminden kadını etkilediği görülmüştür.
Kadın cinayetleri vakalarında cezasızlık oranının yüksek olduğu ve caydırıcı yasal yaptırımların yetersiz kaldığı tespit edilmiştir.
Toplumsal cinsiyet eşitliğinin sağlanması, farkındalık çalışmaları ve koruyucu-önleyici tedbirler, kadına yönelik şiddetle mücadelede kritik önem taşımaktadır.

title: Adalet Savunucuları
text:
Çalışmamızda kullandığımız ana veri setleri şunlardır:

Emniyet Genel Müdürlüğü Suç İstatistikleri
Aile ve Sosyal Hizmetler Bakanlığı Kadına Yönelik Şiddet Verileri
Kadın Cinayetlerini Durduracağız Platformu Veri Tabanı
Medya Taraması ile Derlenen Kadın Cinayeti Haberleri




Veri setlerinin her biri, kadın cinayetlerine dair farklı değişkenler içermektedir. Bu değişkenler arasında suç tarihi, yeri, faili, mağdurun özellikleri gibi bilgiler yer almaktadır. Veri setleri hakkında detaylı bilgi için Veri sayfamıza göz atabilirsiniz.

title: Spatial and Temporal Analysis of Femicide Cases in Turkey
text:
Project Topic
Within the scope of the project, we scrape (optional) a dataset of femicides that took place in Turkey between 2020-2024 and we will use it. We are working with a dataset that has details such as the names of the murdered women, their legal age, by whom they were killed, the reason for this, the date, and the way they were killed. Thanks to this dataset, we can see important points such as the number of murdered women by year.
We can also reach values that will allow us to make various inferences according to the cities and the proximity of the murderers. These analyses will reveal what is happening in each city, and we will have an idea about the people who have lost their lives and how things have been going in these 4 years. It should be able to show how we can prevent this.

title: Spatial and Temporal Analysis of Femicide Cases in Turkey
text:
Key Takeaways

With these analyzes, we will reveal a period of 4 years, not annually. In this way, we will be able to see the situation of femicides in Turkey after the pandemic or we will be able to see in what situations human life is so cheap.

region_counts <- as.data.frame(table(filtered_data$Bölge))
colnames(region_counts) <- c("Region", "Incident_Count")

plot_ly(
  data = region_counts,
  x = ~Region,
  y = ~Incident_Count,
  type = 'bar',
  color = ~Region, 
  colors = "Set2"  
) %>%
  layout(
    title = "Number of Murders by Region",
    xaxis = list(title = "Region"),
    yaxis = list(title = "Number of Murders")
  )






This graph shows the number of homicides in different regions of Turkey. The most striking feature is that the Marmara Region has a much higher number of homicides compared to other regions. This can be explained by the high population density and urbanization in the Marmara Region. In the Mediterranean, Aegean and Southeastern Anatolia regions, the number of homicides is at moderate levels. In Eastern Anatolia, the number of homicides is quite low, which can be attributed to the low population density of the region. In addition, the presence of the category “Undetermined” suggests that the region in which some homicides took place could not be determined or that there were data gaps. This graph shows the need for a detailed analysis to better understand the reasons for the differences between regions.

3 What are the causes of homicide


Code
reason_counts <- as.data.frame(table(filtered_data$Kategori))
colnames(reason_counts) <- c("Reason", "Incident_Count")

plot_ly(
  data = reason_counts,
  labels = ~Reason,
  values = ~Incident_Count,
  type = 'pie',
  textinfo = 'label+percent',
  insidetextorientation = 'radial'
) %>%
  layout(
    title = "Distribution of Murder Reasons"
  )






It reveals that homicides are largely personal or violence-based. Family reasons and emotional/social factors also have a significant share. The relatively lower percentage of economic reasons suggests that homicides are more likely to be motivated by personal conflicts. These findings emphasize the importance of social support and intervention programs to reduce the effects of individual violence and revenge within the community.
